captions.text: What's up guys? This is Kevin from SnowboardProCamp.com.
In this video I want to  teach you how to butter on your snowboard.
Butter's are a super fun ground tricks which combine the skills of pressing
and spinning.

When learning butters first start on
the flat ground
then taken them to a mellow slope.

After that start getting creative with
your butters
and adding them into tricks.
To get a good butter you first need to be really comfortable doing nose and tail presses.

For the tail press there are three things that are
happening.

Moving your hips over your tail,
bending your back leg,
while you straighten your front leg.

Do the same for the nose press, hips over
your nose, front leg bent, back leg straight.
Be comfortable pressing on the flat ground,
then bring them to a mellow slope.
Next you want to add spinning to the butter.
To start wind your body up and rotate in the direction you want to spin.
As you rotate get into the press and lock in the butter.

Keep your head looking around to keep
the butter going.

Once you have the butter dialled on the
flat ground, it's time to take it to a
mellow slope.

After that start getting creative with
your butters.
Adding them into tricks.
Let me know how your butters go.

Leave any questions in the
comment box,

and tell me what video should i make
next.

title: How to Butter on a Snowboard - Snowboarding Tricks

comments.author: Igor Bajic (iggorr2-5)

comments.text:
+Igor Bajic Freeride boards are usually stiffer and you usually want it 
longer because that means it will be more stable. They usually always have 
a directional stance meaning that the stance on the board is set back so 
your tail is shorter than your nose.  This helps keep your nose up in the 
air so that if your are riding in deep powder your board naturally points 
up keeping it from catching.  Freeride boards are meant to really only go 
in one direction although it doesn't mean you can't ride switch.  If you 
are going to stay pretty much on groomers and mountain trails I would go 
with a Freestyle board cause they are pretty versatile. Freeride boards are 
not typically for groomers they are used more for back country.  I 
personally like an all mountain freestyle with a mid flex because I can 
hard charge and have fun carving and also do some natural jumps or man made 
jumps maybe some jibbing. Anyway, Evo can really help you choose the right 
board. 
http://www.evo.com/how-to-choose-a-snowboard-size-chart-and-buying-guide.aspx#shape
And I use this website sometimes to get some opinions on gear but don't let 
their opinions decide for you. http://thegoodride.com/
comments.author: Rednu Sbbik

comments.text:
Ok cool,? but then what is the main difference between free-rides and 
freestyles?
comments.author: Igor Bajic (iggorr2-5)

When you nose press make sure your shoulders are parallel to your feet with 
your back hand over your tail. If you turn your shoulder,  you'll turn your 
board and catch your edge.

Cheers
Reece   ﻿
comments.author: Reece Neal

comments.text:
A reverse camber board will definitely make this trick easier. The 
snowboard tail is usually softer than the nose. A little narrower stance 
will help make it easier to move your weight around over you snowboard too. 
Good luck with this trick!

comments.text:
two questions. First, whats the difference between a rocker and a camber 
board? and second, I ride a Rossignol 150, is that more meant for tricks, 
or downhill? thanks.﻿
comments.author: Lars Walther

comments.text:
thanks a lot mate.
this helped me a lot.
comments.author: Lars Walther

comments.text:
A rocker board has the tail and the nose lifted up. So the board is shaped 
like a V. A camber board is the opposite. Rockers are good for buttering 
and more playful. Cambers are more for downhill and shit. But just Youtube 
"Camber Rocker". You'll get tons of tutorials. I don't know the Rossignol 
150 but I assume it is a camber. To be sure just google that as well.
comments.author: Ari Gold

comments.text:
I don't see anything in the video or comments about shifting your weight 
from heel to toe during the rolls. Biggest mistake I made trying these was 
failing to switch to the uphill edge and falling hard once it caught. It 
might be obvious to guys that have been riding for a while, but as an entry 
flat ground trick I would be sure to remind people to maintain that edge 
control. Could save some injuries!﻿

comments.text:
Mind giving us a tutorial on how to ride switch? I ride pretty decent only 
rode 9 times in my lifetime started last year. Anyways I progress really 
fast, except when I try to ride switch. I always freak out because as I 
rotate my foot automatically pushes me back to regular. I gues I am just to 
freaked out I will catch my edge, since I managed to catch my edge right 
before a jump once and ended up with a concussion. Any tips?﻿
comments.author: Tim Dahle

comments.text: Thanks alot 😊
comments.author: Tim Dahle

comments.text:
You can check out my switch video here: How to Ride Switch on a Snowboard - 
Snowboarding Tricks
comments.author: SnowboardProCamp

comments.text:
When riding switch, first look at how you ride regular really closely and 
try to mirror that onto riding switch. For example: I tend to stick my 
front hand out in front of me slightly, and although it sounds silly, it 
actually helps. Make sure when you are turning you push out with your back 
foot. I noticed that I was trying to use my front foot as that is normally 
my back foot when I ride regular.

comments.author: ken meas

comments.text:
+ken meas http://naturalvitality.com/natural-calm-plus-calcium/
Been throwing this in my water and sipping on it all day at the mountain 
and drinking before runs. If you drink before bed it will help with sleep 
too:) a good electrolyte sup will prob do you good as well. Himalayan sea 
salt and a lemon wedge in your daily water will help keep your electrolytes 
balanced if you cant do the sups. Oh and remember weight should be about 60 
front leg and 40 back leg for most of your riding. Hanging out in the back 
seat will stress that back leg! Peace!
comments.author: Chad Johnson
